fields.application_header:
Welcome to the DOC First-Year Trips 2017 volunteer application! This serves as both the trip leader and crooling application. We hope it will provide you with an opportunity to reflect on your time at Dartmouth and share some of your thoughts about providing mentorship and building community. Through this application, we hope to get to know you and understand what you might bring to the role of trip leader or crooling.

WE DO NOT WANT ONE NARRATIVE. We would like to emphasize that just as there is no “typical” Dartmouth student or experience, there is no specific “type” of person who would make a good Trips volunteer. We are looking for applicants who are thoughtful and genuine in their responses.

Attention '19s taking classes this summer: '19s CANNOT apply for croos, given the conflict of dates of summer classes and Trips. '19s CAN apply to be trip leaders for Sections H, I, and J.

Please email DOC.Trips@dartmouth.edu if you have any questions, any difficulties with the application, or any other thoughts!

GRADING AND ASSIGNMENT PROCESSES

There are two stages to selecting this year’s Trips volunteers.  

  1. In the grading process, every application is read blind and scored by a Reading Committee comprised of the Trips Directorate and selected readers. The Committee only has access to the graded portion of this application, clearly demarcated below. All identifying information is removed, and each application is read three times and assigned the average of those three scores.

  2. In the assignment process, select members of Trips Directorate will use the applicant’s score to place applicants onto a croo or trip. At this point, Directorate members have access to the non-graded section, clearly demarcated below, to better understand applicants’ preferences and skill set. They use this information to better place applicants.

NOTE: Check out these helpful FAQs for Trips volunteers, and these tips for more info on what we think makes a great Trips application!

ROLES

We have created one volunteer application because, while trip leaders and croolings do serve in different capacities as volunteers, the positions require many similar qualities. They both welcome first-year students to Dartmouth through the beauty of the New Hampshire outdoors. They provide first-years with mentorship and a support system from the time they arrive, encourage students to befriend people of all backgrounds, and create a more inclusive Dartmouth beyond Trips.

The differences in the roles are explained below:

WHAT DOES A TRIP LEADER DO? Each co-leader pair leads a five-day trip for their group of 5 to 10 first-years on a variety of trip types, including but not limited to hiking, kayaking, cabin yoga, etc. They are among the first upperclass students that trippees will meet, and they play a crucial role in helping trippees transition into Dartmouth.     

NOTE: NO outdoor experience is necessary to apply—we will provide you with the necessary skills and support to ensure the safety of your trip. We would like to emphasize that over 90 percent of incoming classes have gone on Trips in recent years, many of whom do not have an affinity for the outdoors and might appreciate a trip leader who can empathize with that perspective.  

WHAT DOES A CROO DO? Trips relies on the incredibly hard work of six support croos: Grant, Hanover, Klymbing, Lodj, Oak Hill, and Vox. The croos are volunteer logistics teams of 4 to15 students who work for the duration of Trips to keep the program running smoothly. As a crooling, you will be living and working closely with your team to support trip leaders and trippees on every Trips section. You must be able and excited to work under pressure within a demanding schedule to help Trips provide a thoughtful and fun welcome for incoming students. Please keep in mind that croolings will be expected to be in Hanover from August 16th until September 7th.

NOTE: This application is for ALL croos, so please do not tailor your answers to fit a certain croo.

To better understand the variety of support that croos provide, here is a very brief outline of their responsibilities:

  • Grant Croo spends the entirety of Trips in the Second College Grant supporting all aspects of trips in this area (canoeing, kayaking, nature painting and photography, and fishing).
  • Hanover Croo works diligently to run the complex logistics of first-years’ arrival in Hanover. Croolings move and clean equipment, organize and distribute food, and ensure trippees and leaders keep up with a complicated schedule.
  • Klymbing Croo runs all logistical operations for climbing trips at Winslow and the Darmouth Skiway. Croolings teach basic climbing, ensure safety, and spend each evening connecting with and supporting trip leaders and first-years.
  • Lodj Croo runs all operations at the Moosilauke Ravine Lodge during Trips, providing Trippees with a home-cooked meal, medical attention, and diverse evening programming.
  • Oak Hill Croo runs the logistics and skill instruction for the mountain biking and Adventure Quest trips at Oak Hill and Storr’s Pond.
  • Vox Croo is responsible for program-wide safety and logistical assistance during Trips.
fields._old_general_info: All volunteers must be CPR and First Aid certified in order to participate in the Trips program. Even though we are still in the volunteer application process, it is never too early to get your CPR and First Aid certifications! The schedule for these classes can be found at https://sites.dartmouth.edu/dems/community-training/, and keep an eye out for info on financial aid for these certifications!
fields._old_leader_info: Trip leader availability: Unfortunately, we are still waiting on the college to hear back about the final orientation schedule, but below are the tentative dates that we have scheduled for each section. If this changes, we will contact you via blitz and ask you to update your availability. Thanks for your patience!
fields._old_croo_info: If you are chosen for a Croo you must arrive in Hanover by 9:00 AM on Wednesday, August 17th, 2016. If selected, you will be with your Croo full-time until September 7, 2016. Check NOW (before applying) to ensure that dates of foreign study programs, internships, etc. do not conflict with this schedule. NOTE: If you are taking classes over the summer, you unfortunately will not be able to participate on a Croo due to the sophomore summer schedule overlap with Trips. However, you can still apply to be a Trip Leader!

fields.PENDING_description: Thank you for your interest in volunteering for the DOC First Year Trips Program. You did not submit a trip leader or croo application. Unfortunately, applications are closed for Trips 2017. We encourage you to apply next year.
fields.CROO_description: Congrats! You have been selected as a croo member. We are SO excited for you to join our team in welcoming first year students.
fields.LEADER_description: Congrats! You have been selected as a trip leader. We are SO excited for you to join our team in welcoming first year students. Your trip description and co-leader will be available soon.
fields.LEADER_WAITLIST_description: You have been placed on the trip leader wait list for DOC First Year Trips. We appreciate your genuine interest in welcoming first year students, and we encourage you to complete all of the trip leader trainings so you are eligible to lead a trip should one become available. If leading a trip is a priority for you, we also encourage you to email the trip leader trainer account (doc.trip.leader.trainers@gmail.com) to update your availability with the widest range of dates you are able to lead a trip.
fields.REJECTED_description: Thank you so much for applying to volunteer for the DOC First Year Trips Program. Unfortunately, you were not selected as a volunteer this year. We appreciate your genuine interest in welcoming first year students, and we encourage you to apply again next year.
fields.day0_description: You will arrive one day prior to the start of the first-year trip you are leading. This day will consist of a refresher training and bonding with other leaders from your section.
fields.day1_description: This is the day you will meet your trippees! You will get a more detailed itinerary closer to the date outlining the festivities during that first day.
fields.day5_description: This is the day you will be returning back to Hanover from the Lodge with your trip. You will be assigned a task by H-Croo when getting off the bus, which will help things run more smoothly and help trippees transition back to being on campus.
